The Act may be cited as the "Lavender Offense Victim Exoneration Act of 2017" or the "LOVE Act of 2017". During the Lavender Scare in the 1950s and 1960s, over 1,000 Department of State employees were wrongfully dismissed for alleged homosexuality. Many others were also prevented from joining the Department due to discriminatory screening processes. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State fired employees who were suspected of being gay or lesbian, partly in response to congressional investigations into the "sex perversion of Federal employees" and pressure from Congress regarding the presence of homosexuals sympathetic to Communism. Between 1950 and 1969, the Department of State fired employees suspected of being gay or lesbian due to congressional investigations and pressure. In the early 1990s, State personnel were investigated for being gay and removed as security risks. Actions were taken in 1994 and 1998 to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation. In 2017, Secretary of State John Kerry addressed the "Lavender Scare". In 2017, Secretary of State John Kerry apologized for the "Lavender Scare" and reaffirmed the Department's commitment to diversity and inclusion for all employees, including the LGBTI community. The Director General of the Foreign Service and Director of Human Resources, in consultation with the Historian of the Department of State, will review employee terminations since January 1, 1950, to identify wrongful terminations based on sexual orientation. A report compiling this information will be made public within 270 days. Additionally, there will be reports on the reviews conducted. The Secretary of State will review the consistency of reviews conducted by the Director General under section 3 and submit reports to Congress within 270 days of the enactment of the Act. Additionally, a Reconciliation Board will be established. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on the "Lavender Scare" firings. The Board will contact affected employees or their families to inform them of inappropriate terminations and offer to change their employment records. The Secretary of State will establish an independent Reconciliation Board within the Office of Civil Rights to review reports on the "Lavender Scare" firings. The Board will designate a point of contact for oral testimony from affected employees or their families who experienced discrimination due to sexual orientation. It will also provide an opportunity for former employees to bring forth grievances if they believe they were terminated for the same reason. The Board will review each claim. The Reconciliation Board will review claims of wrongful termination based on sexual orientation within 150 days of receiving the claim. The Department of State will provide necessary information to prove the employee was not wrongfully terminated. The Board will terminate 5 years after the enactment of this Act. ISSUANCE OF APOLOGY. Secretary of State Kerry apologized on January 9, 2017 for past discrimination against LGBTI employees at the Department of State. He highlighted his support for the LGBTI community and efforts to promote their rights globally, including appointing a Special Envoy for the Human Rights of LGBTI Persons in 2015. The Department of State, along with other employers, discriminated against employees based on perceived sexual orientation in the past. The Secretary of State apologized for this discrimination and reaffirmed the commitment to diversity and inclusion. Congress also formally apologized for its role in encouraging discriminatory policies like the "Lavender Scare". Establishment of permanent exhibit on the Lavender Scare. The Secretary of State will collaborate with a public-private partnership to create a permanent exhibit on the "Lavender Scare" at the United States Diplomacy Center. The exhibit must be installed within a year, provide access to relevant reports, and display material from oral testimonies. SEC. 8. GUIDANCE ON ISSUING VISAS.

The Secretary of State must report to Congress within 100 days on countries denying visas to spouses of Foreign Service personnel based on sexual orientation. Recommendations may include eliminating visa reciprocity with offending countries to ensure all spouses receive visas regardless of sexual orientation. The Secretary of State will establish an Advancement Board within the Department of State to address issues faced by LGBTQI Foreign Service employees and their families. The Board will hear testimony on discrimination faced due to sexual orientation and submit reports to Congress with recommendations for improvement. The report on discrimination due to sexual orientation will be private and accessible only to Members of Congress, their staff, and the Advancement Board.
